content: The "Pension Benefits Protection Act of 2005" ensures proper administration of internal revenue laws and nondiscrimination requirements. The Secretary of the Treasury must comply with specific sections of various acts and apply certain provisions of the Internal Revenue Code. Additionally, the Protection of Participants from Conversions to Hybrid Defined Benefit Plans is addressed. The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to address plan amendments to defined benefit plans that convert the plan to one with a different accrued benefit expression, leading to a reduction in future benefit accrual for participants. Such plans will not satisfy the requirements of the Act. Plans will not meet requirements unless they provide notice and election options for participants aged 40 or with 10 years of service. The Secretary shall issue regulations for plan amendments affecting retirement benefits, ensuring similar effects are treated as described in the amendment. The regulations may treat plan amendments as described in communications to participants and beneficiaries. The amendments apply to plan amendments before, on, or after the enactment date, with a special rule for those taking effect within 90 days. The Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 and the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 require certain notices and elections to be provided to participants within 90 days of a plan amendment. The Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 and the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 require notices and elections to be provided to participants within 90 days of a plan amendment, including section 411(b)(1)(I) related to retirement under the plan. SEC. 4. PREVENTION OF WEARING AWAY OF EMPLOYEE'S ACCRUED BENEFIT. Amendment to ERISA Section 204(g) states that a plan amendment by a large defined benefit plan can reduce accrued benefits of a participant if the new terms may result in a lower accrued benefit than the sum of the participant's benefit before the effective date and the benefit accrued after the effective date. The term 'applicable plan amendment' refers to a plan change converting accrued benefits to a different form, while 'large defined benefit plan' applies to plans with 100+ participants. Accrued benefits encompass early retirement benefits and subsidies. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code addresses the treatment of plan amendments that reduce accrued benefits in large defined benefit plans. The Internal Revenue Code amendment addresses reducing accrued benefits of a participant in defined benefit plans. The Internal Revenue Code amendment addresses reducing accrued benefits in defined benefit plans by implementing applicable plan amendments. The Internal Revenue Code amendment defines terms like retirement age, large defined benefit plan, and protected accrued benefit. The Internal Revenue Code defines terms related to retirement benefits, including accrued benefits, early retirement benefits, and retirement-type subsidies. The amendments made by this section apply to plan amendments regardless of the effective date of the enactment of the Act. The amendments made by this section do not apply to plan amendments that have already taken effect before 90 days after the enactment of the Act, if the plan guarantees that the participant's accrued benefit will not be less than certain specified amounts.
